Recorded figures show 70 million sales, during a career that spanned more than seven decades. His prolific output included more than 100 albums and around 500 recorded songs; these consisted of country music, contemporary gospel, Broadway show tunes, love songs, and standards.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/arts/music/slim-whitman-yodeling-country-singer-with-a-regular-guy-image-dies-at-90.html |title=Slim Whitman, Yodeling Country Singer With a Regular-Guy Image, Dies at 90 |first=Douglas |last=Martin |date=June 19, 2013 |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=October 29, 2019 |archive-date=June 9, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190609143720/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/arts/music/slim-whitman-yodeling-country-singer-with-a-regular-guy-image-dies-at-90.html |url-status=live }} Soon after being signed, in the 1950s Whitman toured with [[Elvis Presley]].{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/entertainment-us-slimwhitman-idUSBRE95I14R20130619 |title=Legendary country singer Slim Whitman dead at 89 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=June 19, 2013 |access-date=June 20, 2013 |author=Reaney, Patricia |archive-date=March 10, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310233504/http://www.reuters.com/article/entertainment-us-slimwhitman-idUSBRE95I14R20130619 |url-status=live }} ==Biography== {{more citations needed|section|date=October 2022}} Ottis Dewey Whitman Jr.{{Cite news |url=https://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Music/2013/0619/Slim-Whitman-a-country-singer-had-a-distinctive-high-pitched-yodel |title=Slim Whitman, a country singer, had a distinctive high-pitched yodel |date=2013-06-19 |website=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |access-date=2017-10-10 |archive-date=June 28, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180628153014/https://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Music/2013/0619/Slim-Whitman-a-country-singer-had-a-distinctive-high-pitched-yodel |url-status=live }} was born in the [[Oak Park, Tampa, Florida|Oak Park]] neighborhood of [[Tampa, Florida]] on January 20, 1923.Terry Spencer. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/19/slim-whitman-dead_n_3465762.html "Slim Whitman Dead: Country Singer Dies At Age 90"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304105817/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/19/slim-whitman-dead_n_3465762.html |date=March 4, 2016 }}, ''Huffington Post'', June 19, 2013.{{Cite web|url=https://swampie.wordpress.com/2008/05/17/slim-whitman-a-living-legend-on-the-first-coast/|title=Slim Whitman: A Living Legend on the First Coast|date=May 17, 2008|access-date=October 29, 2019|archive-date=October 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191029213747/https://swampie.wordpress.com/2008/05/17/slim-whitman-a-living-legend-on-the-first-coast/|url-status=live}} He was one of six children {{citation needed|date=February 2018}} born to Ottis Dewey Whitman (1896–1961) and Lucy Whitman ({{née}} Mahon; 1903–1987). Growing up, he liked the country music of [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] and the songs of [[Gene Autry]]. He often sang along with records, but Whitman's early ambitions were to become either a boxer or a professional baseball player. He served during World War II in the [[Pacific Ocean Areas (command)|South Pacific]] with the United States Navy. While aboard ship, he sang and entertained members on board. Liking his contributions, the captain blocked his transfer to another ship. Whitman's life was saved, as the other ship later sank with all hands lost. ==Career== {{More citations needed|section|date=October 2022}} ===Early career=== Whitman was a self-taught left-handed guitarist, although he was right-handed. He had lost almost all of the second finger on his left hand in an accident while working at a meat packing plant.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/arts/music/slim-whitman-yodeling-country-singer-with-a-regular-guy-image-dies-at-90.html?_r=1&|title=Slim Whitman, Yodeling Country Singer With a Regular-Guy Image, Dies at 90|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 19, 2013|access-date=June 22, 2013|author=Martin, Douglas|archive-date=October 31, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191031113946/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/arts/music/slim-whitman-yodeling-country-singer-with-a-regular-guy-image-dies-at-90.html?_r=1&|url-status=live}} He had returned to Tampa after the war, where he worked odd jobs at a shipyard while developing a musical career. Eventually he performed with bands such as the Variety Rhythm Boys and the [[Light Crust Doughboys]]. He was briefly nicknamed The Smiling Starduster after a stint with a group called The Stardusters. Whitman's first big break came when talent manager [[Colonel Tom Parker|"Colonel" Tom Parker]] heard him singing on the radio and offered to represent him. After signing with [[RCA Records]], he was billed as "the cowboy singer Slim Whitman", after Canadian singer [[Wilf Carter (musician)|Wilf Carter]], who was known in the United States as Montana Slim. Whitman released his first single in 1948, "[[I'm Casting My Lasso Towards the Sky]]", complete with yodel. He toured and sang in a variety of venues, including the radio show ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]''. Initially unable to make a living from music, he kept a part-time job at a post office. That changed in the early 1950s after he recorded a version of the [[Bob Nolan]] hit "[[Love Song of the Waterfall]]", which made it into the country music top 10. His next single, "[[Indian Love Call]]", taken from the light operetta ''[[Rose-Marie]]'', was even more successful, reaching number two in the country music charts and appearing in the US pop music chart's top ten.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jun/19/slim-whitman-dies-89|title=Slim Whitman obituary|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=June 20, 2013|location=London|first=Tony|last=Russell|date=June 19, 2013|archive-date=February 17, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190217164218/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jun/19/slim-whitman-dies-89|url-status=live}} It sold over one million copies.{{cite book | first= Joseph | last= Murrells | year= 1978 | title= The Book of Golden Discs | edition= 2nd | publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd | location= London | page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/57 57] | isbn= 0-214-20512-6 | url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/57 }} ===Hit recordings=== A [[yodelling|yodeller]], Whitman avoided country music's "down on yer luck, buried in booze" songs, preferring instead to sing laid-back romantic melodies about simple life and love. Critics dubbed his style "countrypolitan", owing to its fusion of country music and a more sophisticated crooning vocal style.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/10130704/Slim-Whitman.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/10130704/Slim-Whitman.html |archive-date=January 12, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live| title=Slim Whitman|work=Daily Telegraph|date=June 19, 2013|access-date=June 22, 2013|location=London}}{{cbignore}} Although he recorded many country and western tunes, including hits "[[Tumbling Tumbleweeds]]", "[[Singing Hills]]", and "[[The Cattle Call]]", love and romance songs like "[[Serenade (song from Serenade)|Serenade]]", "Something Beautiful (to Remember)", and "[[Keep It a Secret]]" figured prominently in his repertoire. In 1955, he had a [[List of Number 1 singles from the 1950s (UK)|No. 1]] hit on the pop music charts in the United Kingdom with the [[Rose Marie (song)|theme song to the operetta ''Rose-Marie'']]. With nineteen weeks in the charts and eleven weeks at the top of the UK Singles Chart,{{cite web| url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/slim%20whitman/| title=Slim Whitman| publisher=Official UK Charts| access-date=June 20, 2013| archive-date=July 20, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720132110/http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/slim%20whitman/| url-status=live}} the song set a record that lasted for 36 years. In 1956 he became the first-ever country music singer to perform at the [[London Palladium]]. Soon after, Whitman was invited to join the [[Grand Ole Opry]], and in 1957, along with other musical stars, he appeared in the film musical ''[[Jamboree (1957 film)|Jamboree]]''. Despite this exposure, he never achieved the level of stardom in the United States that he did in Britain, where he had a number of other hits during the 1950s. Throughout the early 1970s, he continued to record and was a guest on [[Wolfman Jack]]'s television show ''[[The Midnight Special (television)|The Midnight Special]]''. At the time, Whitman's recording efforts were yielding only minor hits in the US. But the mid-1970s were a successful time for Whitman in the [[UK Albums Chart]]. In 1976, the compilation album ''[[The Very Best of Slim Whitman]]'' was number one for six weeks, staying 17 weeks on the chart. Another number one album followed in 1977 with ''[[Red River Valley (album)|Red River Valley]]'': four weeks at number one and 14 weeks on the chart. Later the same year, his album ''[[Home on the Range (album)|Home on the Range]]'' made number 2 on the chart and accumulated a chart stay of 13 weeks.{{cite book|title=British Hit Singles & Albums|last=Roberts |first=David|year=2006|publisher=HIT Entertainment}} He released "Ghost Riders in the Sky" album in 1978.[https://www.allmusic.com/artist/slim-whitman-mn0000029334 Slim Whitman] allmusic Retrieved 08 November 2023 In 1979, Whitman produced a TV commercial to support Suffolk Marketing's release of a greatest hits compilation titled ''All My Best''. ''Just for You'', also under the Suffolk umbrella, followed in 1980, with a commercial that said Whitman "was number one in England longer than [[Elvis Presley|Elvis]] and [[Beatles|The Beatles]]." ''The Best'' followed in 1982, with Whitman concluding his TV marketing with ''Best Loved Favorites'' in 1989 and ''20 Precious Memories'' in 1991. ''Twilight on the Trail'', his final release, appeared in 2010, 55 years after his first.{{cite web |last1=Brennan |first1=Sandra |title=Slim Whitman Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/slim-whitman-mn0000029334/biography |website=AllMusic |publisher=ALLMUSIC, NETAKTION LLC |access-date=July 24, 2022 |archive-date=July 24, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220724021224/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/slim-whitman-mn0000029334/biography |url-status=live }} In 1982, Whitman's ''20 Golden Greats'' was certified platinum in Australia.{{cite web|url=https://i.imgur.com/aNf84lX.jpg|title=Kent Music Report No 453 – 28 February 1983 > Platinum Albums 1982 (Continued)|via=Imgur.com|access-date=December 26, 2022|archive-date=March 26, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230326023830/https://i.imgur.com/aNf84lX.jpg|url-status=live}} ===TV marketing=== The TV albums briefly made Whitman a household name in the United States for the first time in his career, resulting in everything from a first-time appearance on ''[[The Tonight Show starring Johnny Carson]]'' to Whitman being parodied in a comic skit on [[Second City Television]] (SCTV); he was played by [[Joe Flaherty]], as supposedly starring in the [[Che Guevara]]-like male lead in a Broadway musical on the life of [[Indira Gandhi]]. More importantly, the TV albums gave Whitman a brief resurgence in mainstream country music; he gained new album releases on major labels and a few new singles on the country charts. During this time, he toured Europe and Australia with moderate success. ===Popularity in Europe=== Although once known as "America's Favorite Folk Singer", Whitman was consistently more popular throughout Europe, and in particular the United Kingdom, especially with his covers of pop standards, film songs, love songs, folk tunes, and gospel hymns. His 1955 hit single "[[Rose Marie (song)|Rose Marie]]" spent 11 weeks at number 1 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] and held the record for the longest consecutive number of weeks at number one on the chart for 36 years. ([[Bryan Adams]] broke the record in 1991 with "[[(Everything I Do) I Do It for You]]".){{Cite magazine|date=October 5, 1991|title=Adams Single Breaks No. 1 Longevity Record On U.K. Chart|last=White|first=Adam|url=https://www.worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1991/BB-1991-10-05.pdf|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|page=4|access-date=February 5, 2024}} In the U.S., his "[[Indian Love Call]]" (1952) and a reworking of the [[Doris Day]] hit, "[[Secret Love (Doris Day song)|Secret Love]]" (1953), both reached No. 2 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country chart. From the mid-1960s and into the 1970s, Whitman had a string of top 10 hits. Together television marketing in the 1980s, he became known to new generations of fans. Throughout the 1990s and into the 21st century, he continued to tour extensively around the world. After several years without recording in a studio, he produced the album ''Twilight on the Trail'' (2010), which was his final one. ===Later recordings=== ''Angeline'', Whitman's last album under contract, was released in 1984, after which he continued to tour. musicians in the history of | website=[[Independent.co.uk]] | date=June 19, 2013 }} Whitman's beloved wife Jerry died in 2009. In 2010, after eight years in production, Whitman released the album ''Twilight on the Trail''. He was 87 years old. The album featured western standards such as [[Gene Autry]]'s hit "[[Back in the Saddle Again]]" and the television theme song for ''[[The Roy Rogers and Dale Evans Show]]''. ''Twilight on the Trail'' was produced by his son Byron Whitman and featured many well-known session musicians, including long-time band member [[Harold Bradley (guitarist)|Harold Bradley]]. ==Personal life == Whitman was married to Alma Geraldine "Jerry" Crist for 67 years, until her death in 2009. Jerry was born in Kansas, the daughter of church minister, A.D. Crist, and his wife. The couple had two children, a daughter (Sharron, born 1942, who later married Roy Beagle), and a son (Byron Keith Whitman, born 1957).{{cite news|title=Wife of Slim Whitman dies at 84|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2009-02-18/story/wife_of_slim_whitman_dies_at_84|work=Jacksonville|access-date=June 19, 2013|archive-date=September 12, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912013405/http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2009-02-18/story/wife_of_slim_whitman_dies_at_84|url-status=live}} Byron followed his father into music as a performer and producer. He released a number of recordings with his father, and also toured with him on numerous occasions.{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/37270025/slim_whitman_has_last_yodel_fatherson/ | title=Slim Whitman has last yodel: Father-son act proves popular | newspaper=The Times | date=May 3, 1988 | page=32 }}{{cite web | url=https://archive.naplesnews.com/entertainment/music/slim-whitman-country-singer-who-won-new-fame-with-tv-sales-dies-at-90-ep-512707154-335307741.html/ | title=Slim Whitman, country singer who won new fame with TV sales, dies at 90 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.brethren.org/news/2013/remembering-slim-whitman-the/ | title=Remembering Slim Whitman, the Church's 'Mr. Songman.' – News | date=June 29, 2013 }}{{better source needed|date=March 2023}} From 1957 until his death, Whitman lived with his family at his estate, Woodpecker Paradise, in [[Middleburg, Florida]].{{Cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/13773666/Slim-Whitman-s-Home-and-property-Woodpecker-Paradise|title=Slim Whitman's Home and property ("Woodpecker Paradise")|website=Wikimapia.org|access-date=October 29, 2019|archive-date=November 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116031327/http://wikimapia.org/13773666/Slim-Whitman-s-Home-and-property-Woodpecker-Paradise|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/070598/dss_0705Plac.html|title=Many of the area's music landmarks no longer exist|newspaper=The Florida Times|date=July 5, 1998|access-date=August 17, 2012|archive-date=October 9, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009220559/http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/070598/dss_0705Plac.html|url-status=dead}} He was a longtime active member and deacon at Jacksonville Church of the Brethren. He is buried in the Middleburg Methodist Church Cemetery in Middleburg, Florida, next to his wife Jerry. ==Legacy== For his contribution to the recording industry, Slim Whitman was celebrated by a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] at 1709 Vine Street.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/arts/music/slim-whitman-yodeling-country-singer-with-a-regular-guy-image-dies-at-90.html?_r=0|title=Slim Whitman, Yodeling Country Singer With a Regular-Guy Image, Dies at 90|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=June 20, 2013|first=Douglas|last=Martin|date=June 19, 2013|archive-date=November 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116134438/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/arts/music/slim-whitman-yodeling-country-singer-with-a-regular-guy-image-dies-at-90.html?_r=0|url-status=live}} [[George Harrison]] of the [[Beatles]] cited Whitman as an early influence: "The first person I ever saw playing a guitar was Slim Whitman, either a photo of him in a magazine or live on television. Guitars were definitely coming in."{{cite book|last=Harrison|first=George|title=The Beatles Anthology|location=New York|publisher=Chronicle Books|year=2000|page=28}} When a young [[Paul McCartney]] purchased his first guitar, the left-handed musician was unsure how to play an instrument that was manufactured and strung for a right-handed player. It was not until McCartney saw a picture of Whitman playing left-handed that he re-strung his guitar so that he too could play left-handed.{{cite book|last=Miles|first=Barry|author-link=Barry Miles|title=Paul McCartney: Many Years From Now|year=1997|publisher=Henry Holt & Company|edition=1st Hardcover|isbn=978-0-8050-5248-0|url=https://archive.org/details/paulmccartneyman00mile_0 |url-access=registration|page=21}}Larkin, Colin (1993). ''The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music'': Slim Whitman entry. Guinness Publishing. {{ISBN|0-85112-726-6}} American pop singer [[Michael Jackson]] cited Whitman as one of his ten favorite vocalists.{{cite book|last1=Marsh|first1=Dave|first2= James|last2=Bernard|title=The New Book of Rock Lists|url=https://archive.org/details/newbookofrocklis00mars|url-access=registration|location=New York|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=1994|page=[https://archive.org/details/newbookofrocklis00mars/page/362 362]|isbn=9780671787004 }} The 1996 film ''[[Mars Attacks!]]'' features Whitman's rendition of "[[Indian Love Call]]" as a weapon against Martian invaders (the song causes the Martians' heads to explode).{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22965155|title=Slim Whitman, US country singer, dies at 90|work=BBC News|date=June 20, 2013|access-date=June 20, 2013|archive-date=June 3, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190603113026/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22965155|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=http://jax-cdn.com/news/metro/2013-06-19/story/1923-2013-country-star-slim-whitman-middleburg-has-died|title=1923–2013: Country star Slim Whitman of Middleburg has died|work=Jacksonville|access-date=June 20, 2013|archive-date=November 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116042420/http://jax-cdn.com/news/metro/2013-06-19/story/1923-2013-country-star-slim-whitman-middleburg-has-died|url-status=dead}} In 2003, [[Rob Zombie]] used Whitman's version of [[I Remember You (1941 song)|"I Remember You"]] in his directorial debut in the film ''[[House of 1000 Corpses]]''.
